review_title: Constricting, Rigid and Takes Advantage of the Talent they have
job_title: Director in San Diego, CA
pros: Warm environment, family atmosphere, sometimes feels like working at church
cons: They have little idea how to work with the talent they have. They pay well below standard and lean heavily on minimum wage work-study students. They are not innovative in their approach to the market, often lagging behind others in the same space. There are certain people that love working here for the environment, and because it is a family environment, they don't set high expectations for productivity. Therefore, there are gaps in talent because under-qualified people stay in positions for a long time. They are an aging work-force that also hires former students too often, rather than bringing in new thoughts, ideas, and talent. They also have some internal policies that are rigid, sometimes feel politically, if not religiously motivated. In short, this is an archaic, ivory pillar type of higher education. I don't recommend working here if you are serious about growing your career, and making a salary that fits your talent level. The president is very mild mannered as a public persona, but I have seen first hand red-faced anger over students and staff behind doors.

job_title: Nicholson Commons Building Manager in San Diego, CA

job_title: Administrative Role in San Diego, CA
pros:
If you're a WASPy human who feels Red but can speak some Blue, you're set.
Prefer to settle into a culture of niceness where there's little accountability (unless you're BIPoC or a change agent)? Be welcomed and comfortable.
Want to sink neck-deep into a morass of beautiful scenics and self-reproducing-and-reinforcing cultural norms? Woohoo, you've found your calling!

PLNU is full of well-intentioned souls. There's a resilient core of faculty and employees who realize that good intentions aren't enough; how matters. Outside of that, people will be nice and polite to you in group settings. Move behind closed doors or when you're not around ... there's a serious infestation of whitewashed tombs. The stagnant decay runs as wide and deep as the Our Father's love; I so deeply wish His love informed more of what day-to-day #PLNUlife was like.

There is such great potential in this place, in these people. God clearly is doing work on the campus, but there is such a deep White American Exceptionalism Savior Industrial Complex established in how all the systems and practices and norms and institutions of the University function that it feels like 1 step forward, 2 steps back, 2 steps forward, 1 step back. And after all of your dancing and tip-toeing around the deeper issues, you're back where you started: a community that self-selects its insider members based on how much they align to the culture that is set by those who came before.

There's some powerfully good things from those that came before, but there's some mightily broken parts there too. PLNU, you can and must do better. As long as you bear the Nazarene name, anything less defiles Our King.
cons: A university that bears the name of Jesus that doesn't bear His likeness: culturally, systematically, demographically, economically, fundamentally.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros: Lots of flexibility for personal obligations, doctors appointments and such.  You get an extra week off between Christmas and New Years, in addition to a generous sick time and vacation/PTO package.  Good opportunities to advance your education, either formally or informally, while working.
cons: The pay is lower than what you would earn at a public company, but comparable to other similar institutions.  You are basically choosing lower pay in exchange for better work/life balance.  Parking can be a bit of a hassle.

review_title: Good people, Beautiful campus, brilliant students... Upper management must step up
job_title: Director in San Diego, CA
pros: Great relationships and well intentioned people. Beautiful campus. Student centered and majority students gets their way. Benefits are comparable to other schools like it.
cons: Terrible pay and not enough room for advancement. Still hold on to archaic traditions that prevents young innovation. Because of the great emphasis on student first, students are very entitled. Students may not be prepared for the "real" world workplace.

review_title: Great team environment with strong sense of purpose
job_title: Graduate Enrollment Telecounselor in San Diego, CA
pros: Mangers are great. The working environment and people are exceptional. Employees are treated well with small perks every now and again. The school leadership is amazing. Care about individuals and their fullfillment by encouraging and aiding in getting more education and career advancement.
cons: Pay is not as competitive, but it makes up for that in the work environment. The job is what it is, not super exciting, but there are some good days. As a student worker, there aren't the same benefits as a staff employee.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros: There is a great community of students, staff and faculty.  Everyone is friendly and cares.  The job has a lot of independence, but others are always available to help.
cons: Probably the biggest con is that it is a low salary, especially considering the number of duties and the cost of living in San Diego.

job_title: in San Diego, CA
pros:
POSITIVE ENVIRONMENT: I've worked a number of places that were too competitive, gossipy, and overall negative.  I've never received anything but encouragement and constructive criticism.

BENEFITS: Wonderful package for full-time employees.

LOCATION: literally right on the beach with an incredible view and walking distance to go surfing.
cons: Perhaps the only downside of working here is that no one ever leaves, so the opportunity to go to the next level may take a while.

job_title: Community Service Officer in San Diego, CA
pros: Working in team environments and communicating with college residents helped me to gain skills in customer service. Gave me great experience
cons: Not the best infrastructure, training, or management in terms of giving employees opportunities to grow and thrive. The job did not offer appealing or invigorating challenges

job_title: Office Assistant in San Diego, CA
pros: Great views.  Great people.  Good opportunities to move around and learn a lot.  You can also take classes if you desire.
cons: Expensive to live in neighborhoods close by.  If you are commuting there is a lot of traffic getting on to the point.  Plan ahead and leave early.

review_title: Working at PLNU had been a joy. Professors are personable and the environment is unbeatable.

pros:
Working with wonderful people, including faculty, staff and students. 
Very friendly support staff.
Great work environment.
Top of the line science facilities.
cons: I haven't faced many cons of working at the university. The work hours submission forum has been a bit tricky to transition into but staff are helpful with any questions you may have.

job_title: Director in San Diego, CA
pros: Great students!  I loved the students' passion for the wilderness and need for connection to each other.  The location is great with an unreal view of the ocean.  Great healthcare.
cons: Challenges breaking into the community, most are not local (few can afford to live near PLNU so they're spread out all over SD county) and many are former PLNU grads.  Limited interaction with other pro-staff.

job_title: in San Diego, CA
